Nauru

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Aaron Marrs, February 2009

div.head: Summary
div.p: After several colonial and military occupations, Nauru became a United Nations trust territory following World War II. The country achieved independence in 1968, and several years later the United States accredited its Ambassador to Australia to also serve Nauru. The United States does not have an embassy in the Yaren District; today, the U.S. Ambassador to Fiji is accredited to Nauru.

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Nauru, 1976.
div.p: The United States recognized Nauru on October 24, 1976, when U.S. Ambassador to Australia Marshall Green presented his credentials to Nauru; he remained resident at Canberra.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations, 1976.
Accreditation of U.S. Ambassador to Nauru changed from Canberra to Suva, 1996.
div.p: On April 24, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Fiji Don L. Gevirtz presented his credentials; he remained resident at Suva.
